9. Romanorum clementem a Petro. This statement is opposed to the traditional order of the early Roman succession witnessed to by Irenaeus, iii. 1. 13 3. 3; by Eusebius, Π. E. iii. a, 4, 13, 15, 213 by Jeromedeetr. illustr. 15 ; Otroa. Dum. 12 ; by Epiphanius, Haer. xxvii. 6 (who probably reproduced Hegesippus, see Lightfoot, oum. Rom. i. 329 ff.) 3 and by Rufinus, Praef. iu Recoyu.; who all insert Linus and Anencletus between Peter and clement. Nor does it find support in the Liberian Gatalogue, which placed Clement immediately after Linus. The immediate appointment ot Clamant by Peter is found only in the Clementine fictione (Lightfoot, saa i. 64, 158, 344) which, though valueless historically, greatly influeuced popular opinion iu the West.
